dt: {bc}to so alter or distort as to create a wrong impression or change the meaning
{bc}to introduce textual error into (a message) by inaccurate encipherment, transmission, or decipherment

et: Middle English {it}garbelen{/it} "to remove impurites or refuse from (spices)," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}garbeler,{/it} probably borrowed—directly or from Italian {it}*garbellare{/it} (attested in Medieval Latin of Verona as {it}garbellāre{/it} in 1319)—from Arabic {it}gharbala{/it} "to sift, screen," derivative of {it}ghirbāl{/it} "sieve," borrowed from Late Latin {it}crībellum,{/it} diminutive of Latin {it}crībrum{/it} "sieve" {ma}{mat|riddle:3|}{/ma}

Presumably a word passed from Arabic to Mediterranean Europe through trade in Eastern spices. The earliest evidence of the Romance/Latin etymon is in a statute of the city of Marseille (recording both {it}garbellare{/it} and {it}garbellum{/it} "sieve, riddle") from 1269 (though there is apparently no corresponding word in Old Occitan). The French form {it}garbalé{/it} (past participle of the verb) is attested in a document from Bruges in Flanders dated to 1304. Joan Coromines ({it}Diccionario crítico etimológico castellano e hispánico{/it}) believes the word was first adopted from Arabic in Catalonia, partly on the basis of the half-Catalan phrase {it}grana assaonada{/it} "ripened grains [?]" used in the above-mentioned Marseille statute.
shortdef: to so alter or distort as to create a wrong impression or change the meaning
to introduce textual error into (a message) by inaccurate encipherment, transmission, or decipherment

dt: {bc}the impurities removed from spices in sifting

et: derivative of {et_link|garble:1|garble:1}; in sense 2 perhaps in part borrowed from Italian {it}garbello{/it}, noun derivative of {it}garbellare{/it}
shortdef: an act or an instance of garbling
the impurities removed from spices in sifting
